sn8.12:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā vaṅgīso sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn8.12:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn8.12:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā vaṅgīso aciraarahattappatto hutvā vimuttisukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedī tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn8.12:1.2.eng: Now at that time Vaṅgīsa had recently attained perfection. While experiencing the bliss of freedom, on that occasion he recited these verses:
sn8.12:1.2.comm: The chapter culminates with Vaṅgīsa revealing his own spiritual journey. The version at Thag 21.1:45.1 is more detailed.

sn8.12:2.1.eng: “We used to wander, drunk on poetry,
sn8.12:2.1.comm: This verse is plural, presumably referring to a troupe of wandering bards. | For “drunk on poetry” see SN 4.13:2.1 and note.

sn8.12:2.2.eng: village to village, town to town.

sn8.12:3.2.eng: the aggregates, sense fields, and elements.

sn8.12:4.1.eng: It was truly for the benefit of many

sn8.12:4.3.eng: for the monks and for the nuns

sn8.12:4.4.eng: who see that they’ve reached certainty.

sn8.12:5.1.eng: It was so welcome for me

sn8.12:5.2.eng: to be in the presence of the Buddha.

sn8.12:6.3.eng: I am master of three knowledges, <j>attained in psychic power,

sn8.12:6.4.eng: expert in encompassing the minds of others.”

sn8.12:7.8.eng: The Linked Discourses with Vaṅgīsa are complete.

sn8.2:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ …pe… āyasmā vaṅgīso āḷaviyaṃ viharati aggāḷave cetiye āyasmatā nigrodhakappena upajjhāyena saddhiṃ.
sn8.2:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Āḷavī, at Āḷavī’s premier shrine, together with his mentor, Venerable Nigrodhakappa.
sn8.2:1.1.comm: MS edition inserts a … pe… here indicating an abbreviation, apparently by mistake. This is the only occurrence of this pattern in the Suttas.

sn8.2:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā nigrodhakappo pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto vihāraṃ pavisati, sāyaṃ vā nikkhamati aparajju vā kāle.
sn8.2:1.2.eng: Now at that time after Venerable Nigrodhakappa had finished his meal, on his return from almsround, he would enter his dwelling and not emerge for the rest of that day, or the next.

sn8.2:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato vaṅgīsassa anabhirati uppannā hoti, rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti.
sn8.2:1.3.eng: And at that time Venerable Vaṅgīsa became dissatisfied, as lust infected his mind.

sn8.2:1.5.pli: “alābhā vata me, na vata me lābhā; dulladdhaṃ vata me, na vata me suladdhaṃ;

sn8.2:1.6.pli: yassa me anabhirati uppannā, rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti; taṃ kutettha labbhā, yaṃ me paro anabhiratiṃ vinodetvā abhiratiṃ uppādeyya.
sn8.2:1.6.eng: that I’ve become dissatisfied, with lust infecting my mind. How is it possible for someone else to dispel my discontent and give rise to satisfaction?

sn8.2:1.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ attanāva attano anabhiratiṃ vinodetvā abhiratiṃ uppādeyyan”ti.
sn8.2:1.7.eng: Why don’t I do it myself?”

sn8.2:1.8.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso attanāva attano anabhiratiṃ vinodetvā abhiratiṃ uppādetvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn8.2:1.8.eng: Then, on the occasion of dispelling his own discontent and giving rise to satisfaction, he recited these verses:

sn8.2:2.2.eng: along with all thoughts of domestic life,
sn8.2:2.2.comm: For “domestic” (gehasita) see MN 119:4.7, MN 137:9.3, and SN 54.8:5.2.

sn8.2:2.3.eng: they wouldn’t get snarled in anything;

sn8.2:2.4.eng: unsnarled, undesiring: that’s a real mendicant.

sn8.2:3.1.eng: Whatever here is included in form—

sn8.2:3.2.eng: on earth, in the sky, or in planet’s deep—
sn8.2:3.2.comm: “Planet” is jagatī; both words stem from the celestial bodies who “wander” about the sky. “Planet’s deep” (jagatogadha) is a poetic term for things underground, a favorite place for hiding treasure (MN 128:20.5, Kp 8).

sn8.2:3.3.eng: wears out, it is all impermanent:

sn8.2:3.4.eng: the self-examined live having comprehended this.
sn8.2:3.4.comm: Muta is the past participle of maññati, “to think, to examine”; it recurs in the next verse. The unique term mutattā (“the self-examined”) recalls Yājñavalkya, “when the Self is seen, heard, thought (or examined), cognized” (ātmani khalv are dṛṣṭe śrute mate vijñāta, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.5.6).

sn8.2:4.1.eng: People are bound to their attachments,

sn8.2:4.2.eng: to impingement of the seen and heard, <j>and to what is thought.
sn8.2:4.2.comm: Here paṭigha is added to the regular set diṭṭha, suta, and muta.  I take the line as divided by ca, so that the noun paṭigha is qualified by the two past participles in the first clause. Paṭigha has its regular meaning of any kind of “impingement” through the physical senses (DN 15:20.4, MN 77:22.8, SN 1.23:4.3). Muta is distinct, as “thought” is experienced via “labeling” (DN 15:20.2), not by “impingement”.

sn8.2:4.3.eng: Unstirred, dispel desire for these things;

sn8.2:4.4.pli: Yo ettha na limpati taṃ munimāhu.
sn8.2:4.4.eng: for one called ‘a sage’ does not cling to them.

sn8.2:5.1.eng: Trapped in the sixty wrong views, <j>full of their own opinions,
sn8.2:5.1.comm: Presumably an abbreviated reference to the sixty-two views of the Brahmajālasutta in which the unwary may be trapped (DN 1:3.72.2; referenced as “sixty-three” at Snp 3.6:42.1).

sn8.2:5.2.eng: ordinary people are fixed in wrong principles.

sn8.2:5.3.eng: But that mendicant wouldn’t join a sect,

sn8.2:5.4.eng: still less would they utter lewd speech.

sn8.2:6.1.eng: Clever, serene for a long time,

sn8.2:6.2.eng: free of deceit, alert, without envy,

sn8.2:6.3.eng: the sage has reached the state of peace;

sn8.3:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā vaṅgīso āḷaviyaṃ viharati aggāḷave cetiye āyasmatā nigrodhakappena upajjhāyena saddhiṃ.
sn8.3:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Āḷavī, at Āḷavī’s premier shrine, together with his mentor, Venerable Nigrodhakappa.

sn8.3:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā vaṅgīso attano paṭibhānena aññe pesale bhikkhū atimaññati.
sn8.3:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Vaṅgīsa looked down upon other good-hearted mendicants because of his own poetic virtuosity.

sn8.3:1.4.pli: “alābhā vata me, na vata me lābhā; dulladdhaṃ vata me, na vata me suladdhaṃ;

sn8.3:1.5.pli: yvāhaṃ attano paṭibhānena aññe pesale bhikkhū atimaññāmī”ti.
sn8.3:1.5.eng: that I look down on other good-hearted mendicants because of my own poetic virtuosity.”

sn8.3:1.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso attanāva attano vippaṭisāraṃ uppādetvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn8.3:1.6.eng: Then, on the occasion of arousing remorse in himself, he recited these verses:

sn8.3:2.1.comm: Vaṅgīsa refers to himself by his Vedic clan name of Gotama. The commentary says he was a brahmin, which would explain his training in poetry.

sn8.3:2.2.eng: Completely abandon the different kinds of conceit!

sn8.3:2.3.eng: Besotted with the different kinds of conceit,

sn8.3:2.4.eng: you’ve had regrets for a long time.

sn8.3:3.1.eng: Smeared by smears and slain by conceit,

sn8.3:3.3.eng: When people slain by conceit are reborn in hell,

sn8.3:3.4.eng: they grieve for a long time.

sn8.3:4.1.eng: But a mendicant who practices rightly,

sn8.3:4.3.eng: They enjoy happiness and a good reputation,

sn8.3:4.4.eng: and they rightly call him a ‘Seer of Truth’.

sn8.3:5.1.eng: So being not hard-hearted, but energetic,

sn8.3:5.3.eng: and having completely given up conceit,

sn8.3:5.4.eng: the one who makes an end with knowledge is assuaged.”
sn8.3:5.4.comm: The final verse describes the whole Buddhist path in miniature.

sn8.4:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ānando sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn8.4:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn8.4:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi āyasmatā vaṅgīsena pacchāsamaṇena.
sn8.4:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms with Venerable Vaṅgīsa as his second monk.

sn8.4:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato vaṅgīsassa anabhirati uppannā hoti, rāgo cittaṃ anuddhaṃseti.
sn8.4:1.3.eng: And at that time Venerable Vaṅgīsa became dissatisfied, as lust infected his mind.

sn8.4:1.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn8.4:1.4.eng: Then he addressed Ānanda in verse:

sn8.4:2.1.eng: “I’ve got a burning desire for pleasure;

sn8.4:2.3.comm: Both Vaṅgīsa and Ānanda were Gotamas.

sn8.4:2.4.eng: tell me how to quench the flames.”

sn8.4:3.2.eng: because of a perversion of perception.

sn8.4:3.3.eng: Turn away from the feature of things

sn8.4:4.1.eng: See all conditioned phenomena as alien,

sn8.4:4.3.eng: Extinguish the great fire of lust,

sn8.4:4.4.eng: don’t burn up again and again.

sn8.4:5.2.eng: meditate on the ugly aspects of the body.

sn8.4:5.3.eng: With mindfulness immersed in the body,

sn8.4:6.2.eng: give up the underlying tendency to conceit;

sn8.5:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn8.5:2.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā subhāsitā hoti, no dubbhāsitā; anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca viññūnaṃ.
sn8.5:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, speech that has four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.
sn8.5:2.1.comm: While this sounds like a standard teaching, it is only found in this context. A different set of five factors is at AN 5.198.

sn8.5:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu subhāsitaṃyeva bhāsati no dubbhāsitaṃ, dhammaṃyeva bhāsati no adhammaṃ, piyaṃyeva bhāsati no appiyaṃ, saccaṃyeva bhāsati no alikaṃ.
sn8.5:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant speaks well, not poorly; their speech is principled, not unprincipled; they speak pleasantly, not unpleasantly; and they speak truthfully, not falsely.

sn8.5:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi aṅgehi samannāgatā vācā subhāsitā hoti, no dubbhāsitā, anavajjā ca ananuvajjā ca viññūnan”ti.
sn8.5:2.4.eng: Speech with these four factors is well spoken, not poorly spoken. It’s blameless and is not criticized by sensible people.”

sn8.5:2.5.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn8.5:2.6.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn8.5:2.6.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn8.5:3.1.eng: “Good people say well-spoken words are foremost;

sn8.5:3.2.eng: second, speech ought be principled, not unprincipled;

sn8.5:3.4.eng: and fourth, speak truthfully, not falsely.”

sn8.5:4.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn8.5:4.1.eng: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,

sn8.5:4.2.eng: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”

sn8.5:4.3.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

sn8.5:4.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso bhagavantaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
sn8.5:4.4.eng: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:

sn8.5:5.4.eng: such speech is truly well spoken.

sn8.5:6.4.eng: that bring nothing bad to others.

sn8.5:7.1.comm: The truth is undying because the principles of the Dhamma are always true (SN 12.20:2.3). To put it another way, it is never false to say that conditioned things are impermanent.

sn8.5:7.2.comm: “Undying speech” (amṛtā vāco) is found in Vedic context (eg. Jaimini Gṛhyasūtra 2.1, Brahma Purāṇa 219.58), where it means speech that is immortal since it is of the Divine.

sn8.5:7.3.eng: Good people say the teaching and meaning

sn8.5:7.4.comm: The Sanskrit version of this verse translates as, “Truth may be the undying speech, for true speech is unexcelled. Truth and speech are grounded in the meaning and teaching.” (Uv 8.14). See too Taittirīya Brāhmaṇa 1.2.1.25.4, amṛte satye pratiṣṭhitām.

sn8.5:8.1.eng: The words spoken by the Buddha

sn8.5:8.3.eng: for making an end of suffering:

sn8.5:8.4.eng: this really is the best kind of speech.”

sn8.6:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā sāriputto sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn8.6:1.1.eng: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn8.6:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti poriyā vācāya vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā.
sn8.6:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the mendicants in the assembly hall with a Dhamma talk. His words were polished, clear, articulate, and expressed the meaning.

sn8.6:1.3.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn8.6:1.3.eng: And those mendicants were paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn8.6:1.5.pli: “ayaṃ kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū dhammiyā kathāya sandasseti samādapeti samuttejeti sampahaṃseti poriyā vācāya vissaṭṭhāya anelagalāya atthassa viññāpaniyā.
sn8.6:1.5.eng: “This Venerable Sāriputta is educating the mendicants. …

sn8.6:1.6.pli: Te ca bhikkhū aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi katvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇanti.
sn8.6:1.6.eng: And those mendicants are paying attention, applying the mind, concentrating wholeheartedly, and actively listening.

sn8.6:1.7.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthaveyyan”ti.
sn8.6:1.7.eng: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”

sn8.6:2.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yenāyasmā sāriputto tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
sn8.6:2.1.eng: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward Sāriputta, and said,

sn8.6:2.2.pli: “paṭibhāti maṃ, āvuso sāriputta, paṭibhāti maṃ, āvuso sāriputtā”ti.
sn8.6:2.2.eng: “I feel inspired to speak, Reverend Sāriputta! I feel inspired to speak, Reverend Sāriputta!”

sn8.6:2.3.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said Sāriputta.

sn8.6:2.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
sn8.6:2.4.eng: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled Sāriputta in his presence with fitting verses:

sn8.6:3.2.eng: expert in the path and what is not the path;

sn8.6:4.3.eng: His call, like a myna bird,
sn8.6:4.3.comm: Vaṅgīsa emphasizes the aesthetic and emotional qualities of speech.

sn8.6:5.2.eng: the mendicants listen to his sweet voice,

sn8.7:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ pañcamattehi bhikkhusatehi sabbeheva arahantehi.
sn8.7:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery, together with a large Saṅgha of around five hundred monks, all of whom were perfected ones.
sn8.7:1.1.comm: Normally I use the gender-neutral and literal “mendicant” for bhikkhu, but at this formal act of the Saṅgha only men would be present, so I use “monk”. Nuns hold their own ceremony.

sn8.7:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā tadahuposathe pannarase pavāraṇāya bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto abbhokāse nisinno hoti.
sn8.7:1.2.eng: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks for the invitation to admonish.
sn8.7:1.2.comm: This was the end of the rains retreat, during which mendicants stayed in one place. To conclude the retreat, the mendicants gather to invite admonition from each other, clearing the air of any conflicts or tensions that might have arisen during the retreat. This is done instead of the regular recitation of the Pātimokkha rules. Discussed in detail at Kd 4.

sn8.7:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tuṇhībhūtaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn8.7:1.3.eng: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of monks, who were silent. He addressed them:

sn8.7:1.4.eng: “Come now, monks, I invite you all:

sn8.7:1.5.pli: Na ca me kiñci garahatha kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā”ti.
sn8.7:1.5.eng: Is there anything I’ve done by way of body or speech that you would criticize?”
sn8.7:1.5.comm: The Buddha does not hold himself above accountability. Rather, a good spiritual leader shows by example that everyone must be open to criticism.

sn8.7:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn8.7:2.1.eng: When he had spoken, Venerable Sāriputta got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said:

sn8.7:2.2.pli: “na kho mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavato kiñci garahāma kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā.
sn8.7:2.2.eng: “There is nothing, sir, that you’ve done by way of body or speech that we would criticize.

sn8.7:2.3.pli: Bhagavā hi, bhante, anuppannassa maggassa uppādetā, asañjātassa maggassa sañjanetā, anakkhātassa maggassa akkhātā, maggaññū maggavidū maggakovido.
sn8.7:2.3.eng: For the Blessed One gave rise to the unarisen path, gave birth to the unborn path, and explained the unexplained path. He is the knower of the path, the discoverer of the path, the expert on the path.

sn8.7:2.4.pli: Maggānugā ca, bhante, etarahi sāvakā viharanti pacchā samannāgatā;
sn8.7:2.4.eng: And now the disciples live following the path; they acquire it later.

sn8.7:2.5.eng: And sir, I invite the Blessed One.

sn8.7:2.6.pli: Na ca me bhagavā kiñci garahati kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā”ti.
sn8.7:2.6.eng: Is there anything I’ve done by way of body or speech that you would criticize?”

sn8.7:3.1.pli: “Na khvāhaṃ te, sāriputta, kiñci garahāmi kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā.
sn8.7:3.1.eng: “There is nothing, Sāriputta, that you’ve done by way of body or speech that I would criticize.

sn8.7:3.2.pli: Paṇḍito tvaṃ, sāriputta, mahāpañño tvaṃ, sāriputta, puthupañño tvaṃ, sāriputta, hāsapañño tvaṃ, sāriputta, javanapañño tvaṃ, sāriputta, tikkhapañño tvaṃ, sāriputta, nibbedhikapañño tvaṃ, sāriputta.
sn8.7:3.2.eng: Sāriputta, you are astute. You have great wisdom, widespread wisdom, laughing wisdom, swift wisdom, sharp wisdom, penetrating wisdom.
sn8.7:3.2.comm: This eulogy is also at SN 2.29.

sn8.7:3.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, sāriputta, rañño cakkavattissa jeṭṭhaputto pitarā pavattitaṃ cakkaṃ sammadeva anuppavatteti;
sn8.7:3.3.eng: A wheel-turning monarch’s oldest son rightly keeps wielding the power set in motion by his father.

sn8.7:3.4.pli: evameva kho tvaṃ, sāriputta, mayā anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ sammadeva anuppavattesī”ti.
sn8.7:3.4.eng: In the same way, Sāriputta rightly keeps rolling the supreme Wheel of Dhamma that was rolled forth by me.”

sn8.7:4.1.pli: “No ce kira me, bhante, bhagavā kiñci garahati kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā.
sn8.7:4.1.eng: “Since it seems I have done nothing worthy of the Blessed One’s criticism,

sn8.7:4.2.pli: Imesaṃ pana, bhante, bhagavā pañcannaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ na kiñci garahati kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā”ti.
sn8.7:4.2.eng: is there anything these five hundred monks have done by way of body or speech that you would criticize?”

sn8.7:4.3.pli: “Imesampi khvāhaṃ, sāriputta, pañcannaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ na kiñci garahāmi kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā.
sn8.7:4.3.eng: “There is nothing, Sāriputta, that these five hundred monks have done by way of body or speech that I would criticize.

sn8.7:4.4.pli: Imesañhi, sāriputta, pañcannaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ saṭṭhi bhikkhū tevijjā, saṭṭhi bhikkhū chaḷabhiññā, saṭṭhi bhikkhū ubhatobhāgavimuttā, atha itare paññāvimuttā”ti.
sn8.7:4.4.eng: For of these five hundred monks, sixty have the three knowledges, sixty have the six direct knowledges, sixty are freed both ways, and the rest are freed by wisdom.”

sn8.7:5.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṃsaṃ uttarāsaṅgaṃ karitvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn8.7:5.1.eng: Then Venerable Vaṅgīsa got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,

sn8.7:5.2.eng: “I feel inspired to speak, Blessed One! I feel inspired to speak, Holy One!”

sn8.7:5.3.eng: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.

sn8.7:5.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso bhagavantaṃ sammukhā sāruppāhi gāthāhi abhitthavi:
sn8.7:5.4.eng: Then Vaṅgīsa extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:

sn8.7:6.2.eng: five hundred monks have gathered together <j>to purify their precepts.

sn8.7:6.3.eng: These untroubled sages <j>have cut off their fetters and bonds,

sn8.7:6.4.eng: they will not be reborn again.

sn8.7:8.1.eng: So disciples with the three knowledges,

sn8.7:8.3.eng: revere the winner of the battle,

sn8.7:9.1.eng: All are sons of the Blessed One—

sn8.7:9.3.eng: I bow to the Kinsman of the Sun,

sn8.7:9.4.eng: destroyer of the dart of craving.”
